name: Navigation/Location Bar Minimal Height
description:
The idea here is to use minimum real estate used for  the Navigation Toolbar,  and other toolbars, so that you have more screen space to use your browser for it's intended purpose of looking at web pages not space hogging graphics.   This style uses roughly about 1/3 of the height of the original toolbar.    The red outline is the Navigation Toolbar itself and is the most wasteful of the toolbars. 
 
This is one of several styles to minimize size of toolbars, look for other styles under my name, user 12592, that  include "Minimal" in their style names.   Currently there is some overlap in toolbars,  since I've not learned how to reduce the size of the selection bubbles to be within the toolbars height, but it is quite usable.
additional_info:
I removed the search bar from the navigation bar to place it to the right of the menu bar,  so that both the location bar and the search bar have more working space.  The search bar css code is commented out in this style, and is included with my  Menu and Search bar style.  Remember to choose small ions at the bottom of the customization dialog in your View, Toolbars, Customize for this style and for variations of this style.  

You can remove the space wasting drop-down on the Launchy icon (at the far right) with style 13115 (13115).

Variations of this style:  for a larger size for normal use or particularly if giving a presentation a couple of larger versions that still save a lot of space over the original Firefox location bar see  style 10881 (10881), and style 18864 (18864).  

More information on styles that I use can be found on my Tabs page  http://www.mvps.org/dmcritchie/firefox/tabs.htm#userstyles
and in http://kb.mozillazine.org/User:Dmcritchie   -- Styles that affect the Toolbars can be best seen in http://www.mvps.org/dmcritchie/firefox/toolbars.htm 

To properly view the screenshots either right-click on an image then use "View Image"  or  install style 12373 (12373) so that you can see images within userstyles.org in their actual image size unless they must be reduced to fit in the window.

All of the style effects show in the After screenshot are from:
